years Engineers have come up with ways to solve this and the classical way to

that's the P side it sounds for proportional so the P size says oh look
we're leaning a little bit so we don't have to put much adjustment in or we're leaning a lot we better get those move
Wheels moving really fast that's the P side then to calm that down and to stop

integration so we're looking at the past and we're averaging stuff out because if

what's the difference that's going to come out of here and the d stands for differentiation it's the first derivative of the change

a multiplying factor to each of them and if you get those factors right you end
up with a stable system getting the factors right is black magic but it can be done and
interestingly pit controllers were actually invented uh for ships because around the
turn of the century ships got so big that it turns out that humans were really really bad at steering
them because when you steer a big ship you turn the wheel and nothing
happens and then maybe 30 seconds later you start to be able to notice it's
turning but if you instead say oh look nothing's happening you turn the wheel more and more and more it's going to
start turning too much and by the time you notice that you're going to be going back the other way and overcorrecting
and it'll be just like that little guy wobbling back and forth falling over so they had to find a way to fix that and
they actually created mechanical pit controllers that used the proportion of
error the integration of the error and the differentiation of the error and they found that that allowed ships to be
steered a lot better and nowadays on many ships you can actually see the pit
